text: today's video is going to be about how
to fondant cover a cake it seems like it
would be easier than it actually is but
there's a few tricks to it that I want
to share with you in this video as you
can see from some of the cakes that I've
made in the past a fondant base is a
really really nice neat and
professional-looking start point for any
of your decorated cakes there's a bit
more to it than slapping on some
frosting and chucking on your fondant so
in this video I'm going to cover up some
different fondants that I like to use
when you should use homemade versus
store-bought how to create a really
beautiful solid base cake before you
even cover it in fondant to ensure the
best results and the types of cakes that
I like to use for my fondant covered
cakes I'm going to put this video on a
playlist which includes your fondant
recipes fondant frequently asked
questions tips and tricks on how to
cover fondant as well as my frozen
stacked fondant cake which also includes
some fake layers and how to cover fake
layers and when you use fake cake layers
in a regular cake all of the recipes
tips tricks and all of those videos
compiled in the one place can be found
on the my cupcake addiction website and
I will link to that post down below for
everything you need to know about
fondant the type of cake and frosting
that you use for our fondant decorated
cake is quite specific so it could has
been a little bit of time talking about
this I would always use a mud cake
rather than a sponge or a pound cake or
any other sort of cake I always use a
mud because they've got about a week
shelf-life from the time you bake them
which gives you plenty of time to
decorate them and plenty of time to get
them to your guests before they're
actually supposed to be eaten I also
would never use a buttercream frosting
in between my mud cake layers I always
use a chocolate ganache the reason for
this is because the chocolate in the
ganache sets quite firm which gives you
a really nice neat base and it avoids
any bulging between your cake layers
when you put that fondant on fondant is
pretty heavy after all ganache has also
got a great shelf life so that's also
going to last you a week from the time
you make it at room temperature so these
cakes you don't want to refrigerate them
they don't need to be refrigerated for
each cake layer you use you're going to
need a cake board I always use the Mason
I wouldn't cake boards because they're
really nice and firm but if you can get
the sick
at cardboard or the thicker lightweight
cake boards they're great too you want
one cake board the same size as each of
your cake layers so if that's going to
be a six inch and 8 inch a 10 inch and a
12 inch you want to make sure you've got
those corresponding size cake boards you
need some kind of a scraper and a metal
ruler also works here if you can't find
a professional level cake scraper but
just something that you can use to
smooth off your edges a serrated edge
knife and an offset spatula and of
course you'll also need your fondant now
fondants one of those things if I'm
covering smaller cakes or making small
fondant decorations for cupcakes and
things like that
I'll always use homemade because it just
tastes so much better it tastes like
marshmallows and it's delicious
but if I'm covering layers of cake
bigger than about 10 inches then I'd
always use store-bought fondant it
doesn't taste as good it's still
delicious don't get me wrong but it
doesn't taste quite as nice as the
homemade but it's a lot more stretchy a
lot more durable and it doesn't dry out
as quickly so it's a lot more forgiving
as your cakes get larger I would also
always use store-bought for a square
cake because square cakes are a lot of
harder to cover in fondant than rounds
keep that in mind if you've got a choice
in the shape of cake you're gonna do
once you've got your mud cakes baked you
want to let them cool completely in
their tins because they'll come out a
lot easier and then you want to cut off
any crispy edges and this is more just
for the mouthfeel as people are actually
eating the cake it's kind of weird if
you're eating through a piece of cake
and you find these little crunchy bits
from around the edges you can use a cake
leveler here but I always just cut mine
by eye and I'll always cut mine into
three layers don't worry if they're not
perfectly even or perfectly neat because
it's all going to come together as a
really nice neat round cake when we're
done I always use a cake turntable and
you'll see I've got a little bit of like
non-slip matting or draw lining that's
to stop all of my boards from sliding
around and I always have a larger cake
board down first a bit more non-slip
manning and then the cake board that's
the same size as my cake layer because
that allows me to make sure that I've
got a board that can get really messy
and a nice flat surface when I'm doing
all of my leveling your easiest ganache
is to work with starting with dark
chocolate then milk with white chocolate
being the hardest I've let this ganache
set at room temperature for about three
hours so it's not fully set but you can
see it's also not still liquid put a
smear of it down into the cake
which is going to glue our first layer
of cake in place and depending on when
you're going to serve this cake mine's
being served in the next two days so I'm
not going to worry about a syrup coat
but you would brush this layer of cake
with some syrup prior to putting the
ganache on it if you know that you're
making the cake on a Monday and it's not
going to be eaten til like a Saturday it
just gives it a little bit more moisture
a really thin coat of ganache goes down
in between the two layers and don't go
crazy with the thickness of this ganache
because you're gonna have ganache in
there between the layers ganache around
the outside ganache around the cake and
it's a mud cake which is rich already
traditionally fondant covered cakes are
not designed to be served in massive
slices though did you know the
traditional wedding cake size is a
finger serve and it's like 1 centimeter
by 1 centimeter that's what they expect
people are gonna eat I don't know about
you but I have never limited myself to a
1 centimeter square piece of cake at a
wedding it's the best part so once
you've got ganache on all of your layers
and a little bit smeared on top you want
to just make sure that your layers stay
nice and even so shove them around a bit
if you have to and put a really light
coat all the way around the edges cover
it as best as you can to make sure that
you've got no little gaps or holes and
then pop that off into the freezer for
about 15-20 minutes just to let that
first coat of ganache set and get nice
and firm once it comes out from the
freezer you're going to put a ptarmigan
ash on the sides this is going to feel
like a lot it is a lot but we're going
to scrape a lot of it back so don't
stress once you've got a heap of ganache
on the sides of your cake you can build
up the top a little bit and then take
your scraper and you want to scrape back
around the edges your scrapers should be
coming up right against that cake board
which means that your cake should be in
line perfectly straight and smooth with
that cake board and your sidewalls
should be perfect straight and smooth
when you're relatively happy with the
sidewalls use your offset spatula just
to sort of drag that ganache into the
center of the cake and make the top of
the cake as neat and as flat as possible
what you're achieving here is a really
nice smooth base and you'll probably
scrape around the edges a couple more
times and the top to get it perfect
don't worry if you've got these little
ridges around the top I'm going to show
you how to get those off pop that back
off into the freezer for 15 minutes and
just let that coat of ganache set but
you don't want to completely freeze the
cake at this point with you
ganach set you want to soak your offset
spatula in some boiling water for a few
minutes so it gets really nice and hot
and you can see how I'm using it almost
like a bit of a knife just to scrape off
any of those little raised edges and you
should end up with a pretty nice sharp
edge on the side of your cake do not
agonize over the sharpness of your edges
do not agonize over making these cakes
perfect this is how you get a great base
to the cake but unless you're a
professional cake decorator judging
thousands of dollars for your creations
this will give you a perfectly
acceptable base that's really nice and
firm great for stacking and it's going
to look gorgeous when you're happy with
your edges you want to brush your entire
cake with some simple syrup and mine is
really simple take a tablespoon of
apricot jam and about three tablespoons
of tap water chuck it in the microwave
for about 30 seconds till it all comes
together and brush it onto the cake
sprinkle down a generous amount of corn
flour so your fondant doesn't stick to
the bench and you want to roll that out
to about two millimeters or the
thickness of about three credit cards I
always use my rolling pin as a good'n
measure as to how big my fondant is
compared to how big the cake is so if I
know that fondants about the length of
the bulk part of my rolling pin then
when I hold the rolling pin up against
the cake I can look at that and say yep
I've got enough fondant to cover this
particular sized cake so you're getting
out any rulers or measures to pick up
your fondant slide your hands and also
parts of your arms underneath it so you
can keep it as flat as possible and then
just drape it over the top of the center
of the cake using your hand and working
quite quickly you want to smooth out the
top and work any air bubbles that you
can feel out the edges secure the top
inch of the sides because that's the
most important part so it's not going to
tear down and make any little rips and
then you want to pull out the outer
edges or your skirt of fondant before
using the palms of your hands to smooth
down those sidewalls one section at a
time
pulling out the skirt stops you from
getting any wrinkles in the sides once
you're happy your sides are all stuck
you want to push that bottom skirt or
fondant
right firm up into the cake board and
then trim around the outside edge with a
pizza cutter you can pull away that
excess fondant but just check the bottom
of it for any bits that have got ganache
or water and pick those off before you
store the rest of that fondant for the
next time you need to use it
if you happen to notice any of these
little air bubbles in the tops or sides
of your cake you just want to pop them
using just a little pin and push them
back together so that you've got no air
trapped underneath the sides of your
cake I don't know how true this is but I
have heard that that air can expand and
literally blow out the side of your cake
and we don't want that for your really
smooth finish this tool is a bit unique
it's actually called a cake smoother and
it's basically a piece of perspex with a
little handle on it you can also use
something like a piece of acetate or
even a cut out section of an awl x-ray
to get a really nice smooth finish on
the fondant and you can see with my hand
on the top of the cake I'm actually
pushing the top fondant into the cake
smoother which is helping to give me a
nice sharp edge on the edges of the cake
so that's it your fondant cake is now
ready to stack to decorate whatever you
like I always find fondant covered cakes
a touch easier to decorate if I leave
them for about 12 hours after covering
them because the ganache has time to set
and the fondant will start to set a
little bit as well if you love this
